ANDS-Grants.description: Frail older people are particularly vulnerable to a range of mishaps while in hospital. Good care can reduce the frequency and extent of these problems. Quality indicators (QIs) assist hospitals, and clinical service units within them, to appraise their performance, and to compare it to other hospitals. QIs for the measurement of outcomes for the frail aged in the acute care setting do not exist in Australia or overseas. We aim to develop these indicators during this study.
ANDS-Grants.title: Development of Quality Indicators for the frail elderly in acute care
funder: National Health and Medical Research Council

ANDS-Grants.description: We use computational intelligence techniques to reliably learn adaptive natural human pointing and gestures to control an interface on a pseudo-3D display. Highly complex data with interconnections between elements is hard to visualize on screens. Most current tools are operated using point/click/drag on 2D screens. The physical technology to capture appropriate human behaviours exists already, but not the adaptive learning of the syntax & sematics of individual gestures and actions, nor the multi-gesture information fusion required for 'understanding', which could significantly enhance efficiency in e.g. sorting through named entities in an investigation. All of this is done naturally by most human beings, using biological neural networks.
ANDS-Grants.title: Linkage Projects - Grant ID: LP140100995
subjects: COMPUTATIONAL INTELLIGENCE; COMPUTATIONAL INTELLIGENCE; INTERACTION DESIGN; INTERACTION DESIGN
